title.narrative: Political accommodation and reconciliation in Somalia (CDI-SOYDEN-Forum ARC)

description.narrative: Conflict Dynamics International (Conflict Dynamics) leads the implementing consortium in partnership with the Somali Youth Development Network (SOYDEN) and the Forum of Federations (FoF). The program of work described below aims to deliver significant impact towards the following ARC sub-goals: - 1.2 Formal and informal authorities responsible to maintain security perform their tasks more effectively, more accountably and in better coordination, responding to the needs and rights of the population - 1.3 Communities and civil society lead efforts to improved human security independently and in coordination with responsible authorities By contributing to a lessening of conflict at the local level, and supporting governance structures that effectively prevent and mitigate conflict the program of work is also expected, though the creation of an enabling environment, to make a contribution towards other ARC goals, in particular: - 3.1 National and international actors take responsibility for effective and inclusive mechanisms for peacebuilding and prevention of conflict, with an active role for women - 3.2 Government institutions at all levels implement laws and policies and have functioning mechanisms in place for internal and external accountability The program of work comprises two complimentary approaches to lessening of conflict at the local level and supporting governance structures that effectively mitigate conflict: - Program Outcome A focuses on addressing local level human security challenges faced by communities across Somalia as a result of an incomplete reconciliation process by creating and supporting inclusive local level peace architecture. - Program Outcome B focuses on supporting the Federal Government and Federal Member States in reaching consensus on, and beginning to implement, an accommodating distribution of powers as part of the process of creating a federal Somalia.

mailing-address.narrative: 1035 Cambridge Street Suite 10A Cambridge MA 02143 USA

title.narrative: OA Conflict & Stability

description.narrative: Overarching measures for conflict and stability in Somalia

title.narrative: OA.1 Number of programme beneficiaries who report that they see a safer/more secure future for themselves in the area where they currently live

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refer to the people who directly benefit from the programme activities. The exact definition depends on the local context and the rationale behind the indicator and is to be defined by the grantee(s). ‘Safer/more secure future’ refers to the perceptions and hopes of beneficiaries concerning their prospects/opportunities with regard to their safety and security. This includes security in the sense of physical safety or security in socio-political terms (e.g.. human rights, freedom of movement and association, participation in civic and political life - including conflict resolution processes) and reflects the extent to which they believe they have a chance to live a life free from fear in the area where they currently live, while also feeling more in control of their lives. ‘Future’: The time-frame for this indicator is at minimum the duration of the programme (3-5 years), but will most likely be longer considering benefits of certain programme activities might only be reaped after the programme ends. For example, a person who has received skills-training during years 1-3 may have only gotten a job in the last year of the programme. The benefits of this increase in income and improved social status may only become clear in the eyes of the beneficiary during the following years. Thus, grantees must translate the concept of ‘future’ according to the period which they anticipate is necessary for the long-term impact of the programme to bear ‘visible’ results. This indicator is used to gain insight into how the ARC programmes have contributed to the ‘stability’ of the area where beneficiaries live and can be triangulated with data generated through the related life stories indicators (OA.2 & OA.3) which will be collected by the end of the programme. By ‘stability’ we specifically mean ‘legitimate stability’, which indicates that stability is not a goal in itself. We aim towards the form of stability that arises from social cohesion between population groups, and from citizens’ acknowledgement of the legitimacy of existing structures and institutions, both formal and informal and their ability to engage with them. Stability of this nature, giving people a sense of security in both physical and socio-political terms, is a precondition for sustainable development. Rationale: In order to understand and learn more about the impact of the ARC Fund, we must measure the extent to which the ARC programmes have had an influence (positive/negative) on beneficiaries’ perceptions and hopes regarding their future. The ARC Fund aims to have a positive influence on beneficiaries’ future perspective of the opportunities they have regarding their security, safety, human rights, political influence and other socio-political freedoms. The outcome envisaged at overarching level is therefore to ensure that the root cause underlying trends of conflict, instability and irregular migration have been addressed in such a way that programme beneficiaries, as a result, believe they have a likely chance to build a sustainable life in the place where they currently live and become less vulnerable to forces that threaten their existence (i.e. physical insecurity, political instability). This indicator, specifically, concentrates on the conflict and physical and socio-political stability related aspects of addressing root causes. Disaggregated by: - Male/ Female - Youth*/Not youth *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). For countries which officially use a different definition of youth (e.g. South Sudan/Burundi), consortia of grantees can agree to use such a country-specific definition instead. Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of programme beneficiaries who report they see a safer/more secure future […]. The number is not cumulative. Time schedule for data collection: Data collection for this indicator will be collected at the start of the programme, after two years and at the end of the programme (depending on the duration period of the programme). However, grantees are welcome to measure this indicator on an annual basis if they feel such information is useful to collect more regularly.

title.narrative: OA.2 Lifestories of programme beneficiaries who explain whether/how the program has reduced conflict in the area where they live
OA.3 Lifestories of programme beneficiaries who explain whether/how the program has enabled them to better protect, respect and fulfill their rights in the area where they currently live

LL Outcome A2: Women in targeted District Peace Committees have increased capacity to shape and take a lead in peacemaking and support transformation of gender perspectives of entire District Peace Committees.

description.narrative: This is a subset of RA3.SG.2

title.narrative: RA3.SG.2: Number of women DPC members who feel they have the ability to contribute to conflict resolution (disaggregated)

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Feel they have the ability’ refers to perception of the respondent regarding their power or capacity to do or act, in this case, in a manner which serves as a meaningful contribution towards conflict resolution according to programme beneficiaries. ‘Conflict resolution’ means that a peaceful solution has been found to a disagreement between two or more parties. Rationale: This indicator tells us something about the level of empowerment of a vulnerable group targeted by the programme. The assumption is that the programme will increase the numbers of people who feel that their voice matters, and who feel that their efforts can be considered as a valuable contribution towards conflict resolution. If more people feel this way, the assumption is that more people will actively participate and indeed make a contribution or encourage others to do so. This will increase the inclusiveness of vulnerable groups in the peace process. Disaggregated by: Youth*/non-youth, clan, district, state *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of women DPC members who feel that they have the ability to contribute to conflict resolution per calendar year. The number is not cumulative. Data collection method & source: Collection and analysis of women DPC members’ responses on workshop evaluations Schedule for data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: No data yet. Women DPC members are yet to be trained on gender related topics. As of 28 July 2018, a capacity needs assessment was being conducted to establish priority training needs for women DPC members

title.narrative: RA1 Reduced violence and improved physical security/freedom from fear

description.narrative: This long-term outcome falls under ARC result area 1.Human Security and aims to reduce violence and improve physical security / freedom from fear in targeted areas for specific groups of citizens.

title.narrative: RA1.2 (disaggregated) percentage of programme beneficiaries who report they are feeling secure in the area where they live

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refer to the people to whom the intervention is directed. As defined by the programme, they are DPC members. Rationale: Result area 1 aims at reducing violence and improving physical security / freedom from fear in targeted areas for specific groups of citizens. The extent to which citizens say they are feeling secure in the area where they live is an indicator for improved freedom from fear. The reduction in violent conflict is not measured by this indicator but by indicator RA1.1. Disaggregated by: Gender, youth*/non-youth, clan, district, state *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Percentage of programme beneficiaries who report they feel secure in the area where they live, in relation to the total number of respondents/beneficiaries. Data collection method & source: Phone survey of DPC members Time schedule for data collection: Yearly.

comment.narrative: 105 (88%) of the 120 respondents interviewed reported that they felt secure in the area where they live. They also felt that their families as well as possessions were safe from harm. On the other hand 15 (12%) respondents reported not feeling safe in the areas where they live citing insecurity as a key factor responsible for their fears.

Of the 92 respondents interviewed, 84 (91%) reported that they felt safe in the area where they live, felt their families and possessions were safe as compared to 8(9%) who cited not feeling safe in their areas as a result of the threat from Al-Shabaab.

The respondents were asked if they felt safe, 177 (94%) responded that they felt safe for them selves and property while the remaining 11 (6%) said that they dont feel safe the later citing issues related to clan conflicts and Al-Shabab, during the 2018 data collection 153(92. %) said that they felt secure and that their posessions were also safe. The respondents indicated Al-Shabab and clan conflict as the causes affecting their safety.

title.narrative: RA1.1 (disaggregated) number of programme beneficiaries who report a reduction in the past year in the level of violent conflict in the area where they live

description.narrative: Definitions: ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refer to the people to whom the intervention is directed. As defined by the programme, they are DPC members. ‘In the past year* before’. For example, the question will be: “Have you experienced a reduction in the amount and/or severity of violent conflicts in this year (2016) compared to last year (2015)?” ‘level of violent conflicts’ refers to the amount and/or the severity of conflicts* in which at least one party uses, to determine the outcome of their conflict, any kind of violent acts against citizens, including sexual violence, and/or other physical security threats, such as landmines. *Conflicts are defined as clashing of opposed interests, such as inter-communal conflicts, a crime, human rights violation, misdemeanour, civil dispute over land, commercial or family interests, personal status, employment, inheritance, etc. Rationale: Result area 1 aims at reducing violence and improving physical security / freedom from fear in targeted areas for specific groups of citizens. The extent to which citizens report a reduction in violent conflict in the area where they live is an indicator for the increase in human security. The improved freedom from fear is not measured by this indicator. This is measured by indicator RA1.2. Disaggregated by: Gender, youth*/non-youth, clan, district, state *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of programme beneficiaries who report a reduction in the past year - per calendar year. The number is not cumulative. Data collection method & source: Phone survey of DPC members Time schedule for data collection: Yearly.

comment.narrative: 120 respondents were interviewed to assess the level of violence within their districts. The respondents 20 districts. Of the 120 respondents, 37(31%) reported that there was No Violence, 41 (34%) reported that there was Minimal Violence, 31(26%) reported that the area was Somewhat Violent. 11(9%) people felt that the area was Violent. None (0%) reported that the area was Extremely Violent
No numerical targets for this indicator set, only percentage

92 respondents were interviewed from 16 districts. 5 (5.5%) reported that there was no violence in their area, 63 (68.5%) reported that there was minimal violence, 21(23%) reported that area was somewhat violent, 2(2%) reported that the area was violent while 1(1%) said that the area was extremely violent The total respondents who reported that there was minimal or no violence was 68.

Of the total interviewed 186, 126(68%) responded that there is no violence while 56(30%) said that there was some violence and the rest 4(2%) said that there was a high level of violence. This shows a significant reduction compared to 2018.

title.narrative: LL Outcome A3: DPCs improve their ability to work with local authorities in a collaborative manner
RA1.SG.4: (disaggregated) number of communities and civil society groups that report they have the capacity to influence formal human security authorities

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Communities and civil society groups’ refers to the District Peace Committees. ‘The capacity to influence’ refers to the perception of respondents, i.e. to what extent they feel they are capable and effective in their efforts towards policy influencing. ‘Formal and informal human security authorities’ refers to those bodies from the security sector that are targeted through the programme (e.g. the local police and/or a community security mechanisms and/or…), NOT the entire security sector. For this programme, they refer to local government. Rationale: One assumption in the theory of change is that when human security authorities respond to citizens’ needs and rights, they will contribute to the human security situation in the area. Another assumption is that when pressured, informed and/or persuaded by CSOs and communities, human security authorities become more responsive to citizens’ rights and needs. The programme supports the capacity development of the community and civil society actors to do so. This indicator measures the number and % of actors who report an increase in their capacity to influence formal and informal human security authorities. Disaggregated by: Gender, youth*/non-youth, clan, district, state *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of communities and civil society groups which report they have the capacity to influence formal human security authorities - per calendar year. The number is not cumulative. Data collection method & source: Phone survey of DPC members and DPC records Schedule for data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: 84 members of 14 DPC's interviewed to assess their capacity to influence formal security authorities.10 (71%) DPC's reported that they had the ability to influence formal security authorities while 4 (29%) reported that they did not have the capacity to influence authorities

118, 69% 186 members of 17DPCs were interviewed to assess their capacity to influence formal security authorities. 118 (69%) respondents reported that they had the ability to influence formal security authorities 58(31%) stated they did not.

"92 members of the 16 DPCs were interviewed to assess their capacity to influence formal security authorities. 53 of the respondents reported that they had the ability to influence formal security authorities while 39 stated they did not.

title.narrative: RA3 Increased presence of mechanisms to peacefully resolve conflict and of a capable and accountable government
RA3.3 (disaggregated) number of programme beneficiaries who feel that DOP/IGR arrangements are helping to prevent and/or resolve conflict

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refer to the people to whom the intervention is directed. As defined by the programme, they are decision makers and political thought leaders. Rationale: Result area 3 aims at increasing the presence of mechanisms to peacefully resolve conflict and of a capable and accountable government. The extent to which beneficiaries ‘feel that DOP/IGR arrangements are helping to prevent and/or resolve conflict’ is an indication of the presence of a capable and efficient government that is establishing mechanisms to peacefully resolve conflict. Disaggregated by: Gender, youth/non-youth, clan, district, state, gov't level, political class *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of programme beneficiaries who feel that DOP/IGR arrangements are helping to prevent and/or resolve conflict - per calendar year. The number is not cumulative. Data collection method & source: Outcome Mapping with decision makers and wider political thought leaders Time schedule for data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: Six out of six (100%) programme beneficiaries interviewed, including two Ministers and four senior advisors at both federal and state levels, reported that DoP/IGR arrangements are crucial for helping to prevent and/or resolve conflict in the future. These DoP/IGR arrangements are not yet in place. Additional data (including from wider political influencers) will be added once more interviews take place.

4, 100% Of programme beneficiaries interviewed, 2 of 4 agreed and 1 of 4 strongly agreed with the statement that governance arrangements are promoting the prevention of conflict and reconciliation of different interests

8, Of programme beneficiaries interviewed, 4 of 8 agreed and 4 of 8 strongly agreed with the statement that governance arrangements are promoting the prevention of conflict and reconciliation of different interests

Training Manuals have not been developed yet. Currently, assessments have been conducted in Banadir (16 districts), Jubbaland (2 districts), Southwest (5 districts) and Hirshabelle (1 district). Findings from the assessment will inform the development of a gender training manual tailored to the needs of the women DPC members. Male members of the DPCs will benefit from the training that will be conducted once the manual is in place. Through assessments conducted in 2018 , it was established that women focus mostly on the private sphere solving issues of gender based violence and not on issues considered to be male domains. .

comment.narrative: While the programme contributed to increasing beneficiaries' knowledge and understanding of DOP/IGR, there was no progress on options being taken up in formal dialogue processes because: 1) The federal government was still working out its negotiations with the states and also what role the national leaders' forum (NLF), now renamed the National Security Council (NSC) would take; and 2) Within the states, they were still agreeing their strategy for engaging with the federal government. There was also a false start around the Ministry of Constitution's role because they did not secure sufficient buy-in initially so had to spend significant time to build relationships. By 2018, these appear to be on a much more on a cooperative footing and likely to progress. The Consortium was cognizant of continuing to try to build relationships and prepare groups at this time, but also did not want to force an issue when the time was not ripe, especially because of DNH considerations.

title.narrative: Outcome B: The Federal Government of Somalia and Federal Member States have increased consensus around, and have begun to implement, practical and politically accommodating distribution of powers (DOP) and supporting intergovernmental relations (IGR) that meet the unique needs of Somalia: at federal to state, within state, and state-state levels, thereby reducing Somali citizens’ vulnerability to conflict.
B(3): Number of programme beneficiaries who report increased consensus between the federal government and federal member states around DoP and/or IGR issues

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refer to the people to whom the intervention is directed. As defined by the programme, they are decision makers and political thought leaders. Disaggregated by: Gender, interlocutor type, gov't level, DOP/IGR Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of programme beneficiaries who report increased consensus […] - per calendar year. The number is not cumulative. Data collection method & source: Workshop evaluations and Outcome Mapping, supplemented by evidence from workshop reports Schedule for data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: Six out of six (100%) programme beneficiaries interviewed, including two Ministers and four senior advisors at both federal and state levels, reported increased consensus on further engagement between the federal government and federal member states around DoP and/or IGR issues. Five out of six respondents reported complete consensus on further engagement, while one respondent reported emerging consensus and the need for more dialogue. As there has been hardly any dialogue around the DoP/IGR issues themselves, respondents focused on consensus on engagement on DoP/IGR instead of the issues themselves. While there was unanimous consensus around the need for further dialogue, there is little understanding of how DoP and IGR arrangements would look like.

3 of 8, of respondents, felt there was consensus around DOP (Distribution of Powers). Significantly though 5 of 8, of respondents, felt that there was an emerging consensus around DOP. This data was collected in early 2018 so it might be slightly more positive than had it been collected in December 2017

title.narrative: B(3): Percentage of programme beneficiaries who report increased consensus between the federal government and federal member states around DoP and/or IGR issues

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refer to the people to whom the intervention is directed. comment.narrative: Six out of six (100%) programme beneficiaries interviewed, including two Ministers and four senior advisors at both federal and state levels, reported increased consensus on further engagement between the federal government and federal member states around DoP and/or IGR issues. Five out of six respondents reported complete consensus on further engagement, while one respondent reported emerging consensus and the need for more dialogue. As there has been hardly any dialogue around the DoP/IGR issues themselves, respondents focused on consensus on engagement on DoP/IGR instead of the issues themselves. While there was unanimous consensus around the need for further dialogue, there is little understanding of how DoP and IGR arrangements would look like.

3 of 8, or 37.5% of respondents, felt there was consensus around DOP (Distribution of Powers). Significantly though 5 of 8, or 62.5% of respondents, felt that there was an emerging consensus around DOP. This data was collected in early 2018 so it might be slightly more positive than had it been collected in December 2017

title.narrative: RA3.SG.5: Number of options developed in workshops for politically accommodating DOP/IGR that would increase opportunities for decision making by citizens, including vulnerable groups, that are taken up for consideration by a formal government body

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): Modified from original indicator: “(disaggregated) total number of laws and policies - (#) drafted, (#) reviewed or (#) adopted - that empower or enhance decision-making by citizens, including vulnerable groups, that were advocated for within the programme.” Where 'options taken up for consideration by a formal government body' are considered draft policies ‘Increase decision-making’ refers to giving power or authority to citizen groups. ‘Vulnerable groups’ is to be defined by the grantee and depends on the programme context. Rationale: The assumption is that inclusive policies and laws that empower or enhance decision-making by citizens, including men, women and vulnerable groups, will enhance their voice in the type of decisions taken by authorities that have an impact on their lives. It is assumed that an increased voice will enhance a shift towards policies, laws and practices in favour of citizens’ rights and local needs, contributing to more sustainable peace and the prevention of the (re)occurrence of conflict. The indicator counts the number of options that are in favour of decision-making by citizens. Disaggregated by: DOP/IGR topic, drafted/reviewed/adopted Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Total number of different options developed in workshops that are taken up for consideration by a formal body - (#) drafted, (#) reviewed or (#) adopted - [...], compared to the start of the programme. The number is not cumulative. *It is important to ensure laws/policies are not counted double, i.e. a policy drafted in year 1 that has been adopted in year 2 must not be counted twice. Data collection method & source: Workshop reports for options developed and Outcome Mapping to track which options are taken up by a formal body. Schedule for data collection: Yearly

title.narrative: RA3.SG.6: Number of options developed in workshops for politically accommodating DOP/IGR that are representative of the diversity within the community, that are taken up for consideration by a formal government body

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): Modified from original indicator: “(disaggregated) total number of laws and policies - (#) drafted, (#) reviewed or (#) adopted - which are now more representative for the diversity within the community, that were advocated for within the programme.” Where 'options taken up for consideration by a formal government body' are considered draft policies ‘representative for the diversity within the community’ means that options take into account the diverse characteristics of the individuals living in the community, e.g. origin, ethnicity, religion, socioeconomic stratum, sexual orientation, etc. Rationale: The assumption is that laws and policies that take the diversity of communities into consideration, hence representing the diverse range of local needs, will contribute to a more sustainable peace and helps to prevent the (re)occurrence of conflict. Disaggregated by: DOP/IGR topic, drafted/reviewed/adopted Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Total number of different options developed in workshops that are taken up for consideration by a formal body - (#) drafted, (#) reviewed or (#) adopted - [...], compared to the start of the programme. The number is not cumulative. *It is important to ensure laws/policies are not counted double, i.e. a policy drafted in year 1 that has been adopted in year 2 must not be counted twice. Data collection method & source: Workshop reports for options developed and Outcome Mapping to track which options are taken up by a formal body. Schedule for data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: While the programme contributed to increasing beneficiaries' knowledge and understanding of DOP/IGR, there was no progress on options being taken up in formal dialogue processes because: 1) The federal govt was still working out its negotiations with the states and also what role the national leaders' forum (NLF), now renamed the National Security Council (NSC) would take; and 2) Within the states, they were still agreeing their strategy for engaging with the federal government. There was also a false start around the Ministry of Constitution's role because they did not secure sufficient buy-in initially so had to spend significant time to build relationships. By 2018, these appear to be on a much more on a cooperative footing and likely to progress. The Consortium was cognizant of continuing to try to build relationships and prepare groups at this time, but also did not want to force an issue when the time was not ripe, especially because of DNH considerations. With thought leaders, work was done on a range of options on DOP that illuminated possible ways of solving issues and other challenges, which will help inform our work with political decision makers in 2018.

title.narrative: RA3.SG.3: (disaggregated) number of female Programme beneficiaries who actively participate in and/or lead local peace processes

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Female programme beneficiaries’ refers to the women to whom the intervention is directed. As defined by the programme, they are women DPC members. ‘Who participate’ refers to the women who are taking part in activities related to promoting peace and reducing local divides, mainly participating in District Peace Committees. ‘Local peace processes’ refers to processes that aim to promote peace and reduce local divides. As defined by the program, they are District Peace Committee activities. Rationale: The assumption is that women’s participation, e.g. an active role for women in and/or leadership of peace processes will ensure a more fair representation in local dialogue and therefore contribute to sustainable peace building. This indicator gives an idea of the (direct) effects of encouraging participation of women in conflict resolution mechanisms that is done in different forms in programmes. Disaggregated by: Youth*/non-youth, clan, district, state *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of female programme beneficiaries who participate [...] - per calendar year. The number is not cumulative. Data collection method & source: Review of numbers of DPC members, from DPC records and consortium activity reports Schedule for data collection: Yearly

The majority women members have been involved in dealing with domestic violence cases and engaging in community sensitization and awareness creation forums at the village level.

title.narrative: Outcome A: Local communities in targeted districts in Jubbaland, South West, Galmudug, Hiraan / Middle Shebelle and Banadir, through DPCs, help to contribute to: enhanced human security, reconciliation, building a culture of peace, gender equity, and improved confidence between communities and local government and the federal system.
RA1.SG.3: Percentage of programme beneficiaries in targeted districts who report trust and cooperation within the community. (disaggregated)

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refer to the people to whom the intervention is directed. As defined by the programme, they are DPC members. Rationale: One important step towards improving human security is increasing trust, understanding, tolerance and cooperation between groups with diverse backgrounds within the community and civil society. The assumption is that increased social cohesion as a result of trust-building and cooperation will contribute to improved human security. This indicator measures to what extent beneficiaries experience trust and cooperation within the community. Disaggregated by: Gender, youth*/non-youth, clan, district, state *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Percentage of DPC members who report trust and cooperation within the community, in relation to the total number of respondents. Data collection method & source: Workshop evaluations and phone survey of DPC members Schedule of data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: Value above shows VHT and HT combined. Very high trust: 13% High trust: 24% 120 respondents representing 20 districts were interviewed to assess the level of trust and cooperation within their districts. Of the respondents, 1 (1%) reported that there was No Trust, within the community, 13 (11%) reported that there was a Low Level of trust within the community, 61 (51%) respondents felt that there was Trust within the community, 29 (24%) reported that there was a High Level of trust within the community while 16 (13%) reported that there was a Very High level of trust amongst themselves

92 respondents were interviewed to assess the level of trust and cooperation within the community. 2 (2%) reported that there was no trust within the community, 7(8%) reported that there was low level of trust, 25(27%) acknowledged that there was trust within the community, 45(49%) felt that there was a high level of trust while 13(14%) reported a very high level of trust within the community

title.narrative: RA1.SG.3: Number of programme beneficiaries in targeted districts who report trust and cooperation within the community. (disaggregated)

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refer to the people to whom the intervention is directed. As defined by the programme, they are DPC members. Rationale: One important step towards improving human security is increasing trust, understanding, tolerance and cooperation between groups with diverse backgrounds within the community and civil society. The assumption is that increased social cohesion as a result of trust-building and cooperation will contribute to improved human security. This indicator measures to what extent beneficiaries experience trust and cooperation within the community. Disaggregated by: Gender, youth*/non-youth, clan, district, state *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of DPC members who report trust and cooperation within the community - per calendar year. The number is not cumulative. Data collection method & source: Workshop evaluations and phone survey of DPC members Schedule of data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: Value above shows VHT and HT combined. 92 respondents were interviewed to assess the level of trust and cooperation within the community. 2 (2%) reported that there was no trust within the community, 7(8%) reported that there was low level of trust, 25(27%) acknowledged that there was trust within the community, 45(49%) felt that there was a high level of trust while 13(14%) reported a very high level of trust within the community. title.narrative: RA1.SG.2: Number of conflicts that are addressed and resolved by community structures that are supported by the programme (disaggregated)

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Conflicts’ refers to clashing of opposed interests, such as a crime, human rights violation, misdemeanour, civil dispute over land, commercial or family interests, personal status, employment, inheritance, etc. ‘Addressed and resolved’ refers to a situation in which a community structure has dealt with or discussed a conflict* and has subsequently settled that conflict according to the parties involved in the conflict. ‘Community structures’ refers to the District Peace Committees Rationale: The number of conflicts that are addressed and resolved is an indication of the ability of communities and civil society with diverse backgrounds to apply mechanisms for managing and preventing conflicts and promoting cooperation. Disaggregated by: Issue of conflict, status of case, within or between districts Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of unique conflicts that are both addressed and resolved by DPCs that received training on peace diaries - per calendar year. This number is not cumulative. Percentage (%) of conflicts that are both addressed and resolved by DPCs - compared to the total number of conflicts addressed by DPCs that received training on peace diaries. Data collection method & source: Collection of information from DPC records (mainly peace diaries) and regular communication between SOYDEN and DPCs Time schedule for data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: This data is still being gathered, as Peace Diary training was ongoing in Fall 2017. However, 99 respondents (97%) reported that DPCs were effectively resolving conflict.

title.narrative: RA1.SG.2: Percentage of conflicts that are addressed and resolved by community structures that are supported by the program (disaggregated)

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Conflicts’ refers to clashing of opposed interests, such as a crime, human rights violation, misdemeanour, civil dispute over land, commercial or family interests, personal status, employment, inheritance, etc. ‘Addressed and resolved’ refers to a situation in which a community structure has dealt with or discussed a conflict* and has subsequently settled that conflict according to the parties involved in the conflict. ‘Community structures’ refers to the District Peace Committees Rationale: The number of conflicts that are addressed and resolved is an indication of the ability of communities and civil society with diverse backgrounds to apply mechanisms for managing and preventing conflicts and promoting cooperation. Disaggregated by: Issue of conflict, status of case, within or between districts Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Percentage of conflicts that are both addressed and resolved by DPCs - compared to the total number of conflicts addressed by DPCs that received training on peace diaries. Data collection method & source: Collection of information from DPC records (mainly peace diaries) and regular communication between SOYDEN and DPCs Time schedule for data collection: Yearly

title.narrative: RA1.SG.1 Number of programme beneficiaries who report that informal human security authorities targeted through the programme are responsive to the needs and rights of the population (disaggregated)

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Informal human security authorities’ refers to District Peace Committees ‘Responsive to the needs and rights’ for this programme means effectively resolving conflicts. More broadly, it refers to the extent to which programme beneficiaries feel that security authorities take action to address needs and rights of the population, especially towards the disadvantaged / underprivileged groups. The actions may include: invite programme beneficiaries to participate in (consultation) meetings, putting specific rights and needs on the (political) agenda, develop new policies or laws, take policy measures, adjust existing policies or laws, start implementing laws and policies, etc. [See also Data collection method]. ‘The population’ refers to the group of programme beneficiaries as defined by the grantee. Rationale: The assumption in the theory of change is that when formal and informal human security authorities adequately respond to citizens’ needs and rights – ‘adequately’ in the eyes of key informants - , they will positively contribute to the human security situation in the area. Increasing the responsiveness of these authorities is an important element of the programme which has to be monitored by this indicator. The indicator measures the development of responsiveness of the authorities. Disaggregated by: Gender, youth*/non-youth, clan, district, state *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of programme beneficiaries who report that targeted (in)formal human security authorities are responsive - per calendar year. The number is not cumulative, i.e. you do not add this year’s number to last year’s number when you report. Data collection method & source: Phone survey of DPC members Time schedule for data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: "DPC: 96, 94% Local Govt: 6, 100% Respondents reported that DPCs were actively supporting reconciliation and responsive local governance structures. According to interviewees, the Peace Committees have been able to prevent the escalation of conflicts, are respected, and the communities have seen the benefits of peace and co-existence in the society. Their intervention has resulted in increased trust, community interaction, and mutual respect. Six out of six district administrators (including district commissioners, deputy district commissioners, and a deputy governor) reported that DPCs were resolving conflict and restoring trust between communities. This change has been attributed to the district administrators having more knowledge on work being done by the committees as well as an increase in interactions. District administrators have participated in joint trainings with DPCs and have held joint monthly meetings. Due to difficulty in accessing community members, it was not possible to hold focus groups with community members for year 1, however it is planned for year 2. "

title.narrative: B2.1: Different influential groups, including women, have participated in facilitated dialogue and understand their own and others' perspectives on DOP and IGR options
B2.1(1): Number of political thought leader participants who report that the dialogues have increased their understanding of perspectives on DOP and IGR

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Political thought leader’ refers to influential and politically active individuals who are not directly connected to people in government, such as members of civil society, women’s, and youth groups. Rationale: Disaggregated by: Gender, stakeholder type, age, clan, region Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of dialogue attendees who report the dialogues increased their understanding of perspectives on DOP/IGR - per calendar year. The number is not cumulative. Data collection method & source: Answers on workshop/dialogue evaluations, supplemented by anecdotal evidence from workshop/dialogue reports Schedule for data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: A total of 18 (2 female) participated a conversation on supporting DoP and IGR in Somalia, the participants included member of parliament, of the 12 respondents who filled the post workshop assessment 9(75%) of them said that the conversation increased their understanding in DOP and IGR

January to August 2018: four workshops were held with the Federal Negotiation Technical Committee (FNTC) on DOP/IGR, fiscal federalism and the justice model to enhance their knowledge on federalism as well as equip them with the technical expertise in negotiating constitutional arrangements for Somalia. The FNTC is a committee tasked to drive forward negotiations on federalism including the elections model, resource sharing and allocation of powers, to support political agreements at the leadership level. The workshops have contributed to increasing beneficiaries' knowledge and understanding of Distribution of Powers/Inter governmental relations As per the Post workshop data collected after the January workshop,15 said that the workshop increased their understanding and provided them with a deeper knowledge on IGR and DOP while only 1 respondent said it did not improve his understanding. Similarly the data collected after the workshop conducted in March,15 of the interviewed respondents said that the training had improved their understanding while the remaining 1 said that the workshop did not improve their knowledge.

This is based on the first DOP/IGR workshop, completed within the first quarter. 18 out of 19 respondents rated the workshop a 4 or a 5 when asked the question, "Did the workshop increase your understanding of perspectives on DoP and IGR? (1-5)," with 5 being the most positive. Q2 Update: Research on gender & federalism started

title.narrative: LL Outcome A1: DPCs in targeted areas have increased capacity to sustainably manage and resolve local conflicts and build trust within and between communities.
RA3.SG.2: Number of programme beneficiaries who feel they have the ability to contribute to conflict resolution (disaggregated)

description.narrative: Precise Definition(s): ‘Programme beneficiaries’ refer to the people to whom the intervention is directed. As defined by the programme, they are trained DPC members. ‘Feel they have the ability’ refers to perception of the respondent regarding their power or capacity to do or act, in this case, in a manner which serves as a meaningful contribution towards conflict resolution according to programme beneficiaries. ‘Conflict resolution’ means that a peaceful solution has been found to a disagreement between two or more parties. Rationale: This indicator tells us something about the level of empowerment of the vulnerable groups that are targeted by the programme. The assumption is that the programme will increase the numbers of people who feel that their voice matters, and who feel that their efforts can be considered as a valuable contribution towards conflict resolution. If more people feel this way, the assumption is that more people will actively participate and indeed make a contribution or encourage others to do so. This will increase the inclusiveness of vulnerable groups in the peace process. Disaggregated by: Gender, youth*/non-youth, clan, district, state *Youth is defined as persons of the ages between 15 and 24 (established UN definition). Calculation/Unit of Measurement: Number of DPC members who feel that they have the ability to contribute to conflict resolution per calendar year. The number is not cumulative. Data collection method & source: Collection and analysis of DPC members’ responses on workshop evaluations Schedule for data collection: Yearly

comment.narrative: A total of 134 DPC members were interviewed to gauge their ability to contribute to conflict resolution. Of the 134 members, 85 were male and 49 were female. 98% (131) of the respondents stated that they had the ability to contribute to conflict resolution while 2% (3) of the respondents were not confident enough.

A total of 46(14 Female) people have been trained on conflict resolution in Abdiaziz and Waberi Districts of Mogdishu. The training was participated by 32 DPC members 14 other participants from the Police and security officials and the district adminstration. 85% of respondents told that the training improved their capacity to resolve conflict.
